     Mr K. Shanmugam (Sembawang GRC): Sir, I will try the thankless task of speaking after the SM. The questions that have been asked about the HPL purchases by the Senior Minister and DPM, I think go straight to the heart of a basic principle on which the Senior Minister has built his entire political legacy. The principle that personal integrity or the core of our leadership is completely beyond any question or reproach. Since the questions have been raised, the facts have been set out clearly, the two Ministers have subjected themselves and their conduct to searching examination. And on the facts that have come out, a right thinking person can only conclude that there is nothing in the conduct of either of the two Ministers which can be the subject of the slightest reproach. Having said that, I think it is worth considering the nature and the merits of the questions that have been raised outside this House and compare them against the facts. And I think that exercise will show that there is no basis for any criticism.

    To me, there seems to be two underlying themes to the questions that have been raised. First, some have said that as Ministers, the Senior Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister should not have received their discounts. Second, some go

Column: 346

even further and are unhappy about the very fact that the two Ministers had purchased the flats before the flats were officially launched for sale. The often unstated assumption is that the Ministers had in some way used their public positions to obtain an unfair advantage or had in some way been privileged.

    Both these questions primarily raise the issue of whether the SM and DPM had in any way used their public offices for private gain. If they did, then they would have done wrong. If they did not, then that quite simply is the end of the matter. For purposes of this debate, that is the issue and the only issue, and it is a very narrow question.

    With that in mind, I will deal with the first criticism that the two Ministers should not have accepted any discount. To me, this argument appears to be utterly divorced from reality. They purchased the flats like other purchasers who were successful. They received discounts like several other purchasers, except for one unit in the case of DPM for which there were special reasons. Everyone who buys a flat knows that it is a standard marketing technique and others have said that in this House. It is also standard industry practice to offer discounts to early purchasers. Often, these early purchasers would include those connected to the project, like lawyers, architects and so on. To my knowledge, when my firm is involved in a project, the lawyers will be offered some units, often at discounts at the rates given to other early purchasers.

    In the case of Scotts 28 development, a partner of mine was offered a unit at a price. He asked what the list price was and was told that there was no such thing. He just had to accept or not accept the price quoted. In that context, to say that there was a discount from the list price is quite meaningless. I think that really disposes of the first argument as regards three of the four properties that were purchased. The whole issue is not whether one received a discount or did not receive a discount. The issue is whether a special favour, in money terms, was given by reason of position. The two Ministers received a standard discount, neither bargained.

Column: 347

Both bought properties at a time when the market was relatively soft and paid prices which were higher than that prevailing for similar locations. There was no use or abuse of public office.

    As regards the unit in respect of which the DPM received a 12% discount, let us consider the facts. He had chosen a unit at a lower discount. HPL had double booked that unit. Having previously told him that the unit was available, HPL found itself in the slightly embarrassing situation of having to tell him that the unit was no longer available. How do you tell the DPM the unit he chose is not available? He has to be persuaded to let go off that unit and, at the same time, HPL hardly wants to lose the DPM as a customer. And let us face facts. If the SM and DPM buy HPL properties, that fact alone is worth millions of dollars to HPL. Others will buy too and future developments by HPL can be priced almost at HPL's will.

    There are two ways of approaching this issue of the 12% discount. I am prepared to accept that those are the facts and I have no doubt that most others will do so too. However, assume that, for argument sake, one wishes to argue that what the DPM has said should be disregarded and that in fact a special and unfair benefit was probably given to him. Is that a tenable argument? It would, in my view, be quite untenable. Let us be sensible. Can it be believed that HPL chose to give a special and unfair advantage to the DPM over others? Who were the other purchasers? Would HPL give a special benefit to the DPM that it would not at the same time offer to SM? To believe that would be tantamount to saying that HPL effectively told the Senior Minister that he was not as important as the DPM, or that the DPM was corruptible whereas the SM was not. Everyone knows how the SM and DPM would react to any such suggestions. Would not HPL be asking for trouble? And would HPL really dare to try and play games between SM and DPM? Who in Singapore would dare? As it were, to say to the SM that he was not as important as his son and effectively thumb their noses at the SM and/or say to him that his son

Column: 348

can be tempted while the SM cannot be trifled with, I think that is just plain absurd, and businessman like Ong Beng Seng is not that silly.

    Let me now deal with the second argument that somehow the Ministers were privileged in being able to purchase the flats before they were launched. Again, if the two Ministers had used their positions in a hot market to get on to the list of purchasers, then that would have been wrong. But that is not the case here. This criticism arises, in my view, from an unfortunate telescoping of different time periods. In 1996, the market was hot. In 1995, the market was relatively soft. In 1996, people were rushing to buy the properties in the two HPL developments. In 1995, HPL was not sure that it could sell these units and had to consider carefully how it was going to sell. With their 1996 perceptions of a hot market, people appeared to be quick to jump to the conclusion that the two Ministers were privileged in being able to get to buy these properties which others could not.

    In 1995, when these units were offered, not everyone who was offered bought. Partners of mine knew about them and were not interested. One of them showed enough interest and was offered a unit at the soft launch. He decided against buying. Prices were high, direction of the market was uncertain. In that situation, the two Ministers made their own judgment and bought. I cannot see any argument for privilege. So when one judges them, you look at the situation as it was in 1995. And this may not be polite to say, but let me be honest and say this. When I first heard about the discounts without knowing of the time and the purchases were made, it did cross my mind as to how these discounts could have been obtained properly when everyone else could not buy these properties. But once the facts were brought to light, the situation is clear. It is clear, I think, and I would urge Singaporeans therefore to consider the facts carefully without cynicism and with an open mind. They would then conclude that there was no abuse of public positions and no wrongdoing of any sort. There is therefore no basis for criticising either of their conduct.

Column: 349



    The SM yesterday touched on the issues of equity, ethics and fairness. On the facts again, it is difficult to see what advantage was taken which in any way was inequitable, unethical or unfair. But as to the broader question of whether in a hot market when there is a rush for a few units, whether people of influence should get priority because of who they are, that is a more difficult question which raises not only issues of equity, ethics and fairness but also public perception of how people in high public office are expected to behave. But that is not the subject of debate today. Those are not the facts we have. That situation should be addressed separately and I do not think that can be brushed off as being an unimportant issue.

    Sir, I would also make some observations on what Mr Chiam said yesterday. Mr Chiam raised the issue of Ministerial salaries again and said that this was the reason for the public concern over these purchases. I think we should keep the issues separate. On salaries, I will say to Mr Chiam again what I have said previously. We should ask what kind of persons do we want as Ministers. It is accepted, I think, (1) public office is a calling; (2) it requires a person with interest in society and a desire to contribute to change things; and (3) such a person must be exceptionally bright. The point is this. When one considers accepting public office, the questions you want that person to ask himself are: (1) Can I contribute? (2) Am I good enough? (3) Am I cut out for this job? (4) Do I have the motivation? You do not want him to ask another question: can I afford it?

    If the potential Minister is of the highest calibre, then you would either agree he would be earning very well or will have the potential to do so. Such a person in general might be willing to serve in public office only when there is no substantial financial sacrifice involved in the move. It must be seemless so far as the financial aspects are considered. Money should not be an attraction but neither should it be an impediment. That is the real point that I think Mr Chiam should accept.

    Sir, this whole episode highlights another very important feature of our

Column: 350

system which I would like to say a few words on. I started my speech by saying that the SM has built his entire political legacy on his integrity and incorruptibility. The Prime Minister has also made that as his principal foundation. The PM's actions in this matter illustrate that and his own personal convictions and the manner in which he has discharged his constitutional responsibilities. I think the House should recognise that.

    Let me elaborate. When it was first brought to the Prime Minister's attention that questions were being asked about the property purchases, he had two options. It did not touch on him personally and he could have pretended that nothing was happening. However, the Government would have lost some credibility because in our society, a whispering campaign which was going on about financial integrity which is not rebutted can be cancerous and vicious.

    The second and more difficult option would be to investigate. To his credit, the Prime Minister asked for an investigation after consulting some of his Ministers, but did not consult the Senior Minister or the DPM. What the Prime Minister did illustrates two fundamental constitutional principles which underpin our entire political and legal system and they are: first, the rule of law and equality before the law. No matter who it is, everyone is equal before the law. Everyone, including the SM and DPM, is subject to it. The principle should be that if anyone does any wrong, the law would be applied. That the PM disregarded the fact that the two Ministers, being the Senior Minister and Deputy Prime Minister and ordered their conduct to be investigated, is the best example one can get of the application of this rule.

    Second, the proper discharge of constitutional responsibilities by the Prime Minister. You can have the best constitution in the world with nice-sounding phrases about equality before the law, rule of law and so on, however, if you do not have persons of character and integrity to discharge the responsibilities properly, then that constitution would be a worthless piece of paper. It is men and

Column: 351

women of character and integrity who make it work. The Prime Minister discharged his constitutional responsibilities by ordering an investigation. I think few appreciate the enormity of that decision. Here was a very formidable man, the patriarch of the state, and to decide to investigate him and the DPM was a very brave decision, and a correct one.

    Singaporeans will now know one thing for certain. If the SM and DPM can be investigated, then anyone can be investigated. I think that realisation will help dispel any doubts as to whether the creed of political honesty and integrity has been successfully passed on from the SM to the second generation. That may perhaps be the most important result achieved out of this whole matter. And when judgment is passed on Senior Minister's political legacy, it would be an important, if not the most important aspect of that legacy that he has successfully institutionalised the

Column: 352

principle of integrity in the top leadership. And the best example of that came when he himself was ordered to be investigated.
